article_title: A Classics Collection of Philippine Dance
text:
Published 2006, 2007, 2008 in series. Manila: Philippine Folk Dance Society (PFDS).

The three volumes contain dances selected from previous publications on folk dances: Philippine National Dances by Francisca Reyes-Tolentino (New York: Silver Burdett, 1946); six volumes of Philippine Folk Dances by Francisca Reyes-Aquino (Quezon City: Kayumanggi Press, 1950-1976); Philippine Folk Dances and Songs (Manila: Bureau of Public Schools, 1966); Philippine Folk Dances from Pangasinan by Jovita Sison Friese (New York: Vantage Press, 1980); Samar Folk Dances by Juan C. Miel (Samar Province: 1973); and three volumes of Visayas Folk Dances by Libertad V. Fajardo (Manila: Solidaridad Press, 1961-1975). It also includes dances from previous dance workshops of the PFDS, such as the tutup (Sulu food covering) dance taught by Hadji Badria Jajurie in a 1982 dance workshop and the takiling (a kind of bird) of the Kalinga taught by Ramon Obusan in 1988.

The featured dances are identified by provinces or regions, two of which are categorized as “national:” cariñosa (charming) and surtido (sorted/combined). Each volume follows the long-established arrangement of dances in varied functions and regional provenance so as to fit or sustain both the curricular interest and performance repertory. This format also dictates how the annual workshops of PFDS are conducted. Volume 1 has alcamfor (alcamfor flower) of Leyte; binasuan (drinking glass filled with local wine) of Pangasinan; cariñosa; habanera botoleña (habanera of Botolan) of Zambales; imunan (jealousy) of Pangasinan; itik-itik (duck-like) of Surigao; kandingan (from the percussive instrument,gandang) of Jolo; kuratsa (from the Mexican kukuracha or cockroach dance) of Leyte; los bailes de ayer (dances of yesterday) of Tarlac; maglalatik or magbabao (coconut oil-maker or coconut shell-maker) from Laguna; pandango/pandanggo sa ilaw (fandango with light) and polkabal (polka and waltz combined) both from Mindoro; and surtido specifically in Ilocos, Pampanga, Tagalog, Bicol, and the Visayas.

Volume 2 has dinuya (striking wooden pegs) from the Mountain Province; estudiantina (for students) and jotabal (jota and waltz combined) both of Quezon; kapiil sa munsala (handkerchief dance) of Lanao; palok (a festival dance) of Kalinga; pasakat (pas de quatre) of Laguna; paseo (stroll) de Bicol of Albay; and sakuting (stick dance) of Abra.

Volume 3 has dagit-dagit (to swoop) of Capiz; habisanan (from “haba” in habanera and “sinan” of Pangasinan); jota ha kalipay (joyful jota) of Samar; lanceros (lancers) de Lingayen of Pangasinan; las panderita (tambourines) of Iloilo; liki (shifting moves) of Negros Occidental; oasioas (lights in kerchiefs) of Pangasinan; sala ti alat (dance with fish basket) of Zambales; takiling (a kind of bird) of Kalinga; and tutup (food cover) of Sulu. Improvements from the original black-and-white editions are the prominent attributions between regions and researchers, well laid out dance instruction and musical scoring, and some colored pictures as full-page illustrations.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

Published 2006. Author, Lisa Macuja-Elizalde with Angela Baldrony Ureta and Susan A. de Guzman as coauthors and editors. Pasay City: Ballet Manila Foundation, Inc

The coffee-table book is the autobiography of ballerina Lisa Macuja-Elizalde told in three acts. The first act “Adagio” begins as a story of an ordinary eight-year-old student for whom ballet was a hobby chosen by her mother for her. It chronicles the girl’s growth and discipline as a dancer, her apprenticeship as a young soloist for Dance Theater Philippines, and her leaving the Philippines upon receiving a scholarship to the Leningrad Choreographic School. The second act “Allegro” presents a young lady’s life as a foreign student in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, later becoming the first foreign solo dancer of the Kirov Ballet after her graduation from Leningrad. The final act “Pas Jete” narrates Macuja-Elizalde’s coming home to become a Philippine-based artist performing in major productions in various places in the country and as an international guest dancer in Europe, the North Americas, and Asia. It covers her life as the first artist-in-residence of the Cultural Center of the Philippines while dancing with Ballet Philippines, and later with Philippine Ballet Theatre as principal ballerina. With her exposure as dancer on television, she became an icon of ballet in the popular imagination, and a founder of Ballet Manila, of which she later became artistic director.

The claim of the book’s title, Ballerina of the People, is based on Macuja-Elizalde’s conscious attempts to bring ballet closer to the Filipinos in the provinces, as she had done in outreach projects of Pamana Ballet, Dance Theater Philippines, Ballet Philippines, and Philippine Ballet Theatre. Her visibility in media has made Philippine ballet more accessible to the public. But critics derided her for debasing the art by advertising for a sanitary napkin and appearing on television and pop events, giving her the tags “Napkin Queen” and “Ballerinang Bakya.” Another goal of Macuja-Elizalde is to broaden audience viewership by making Ballet Manila’s performances affordable in the Star City entertainment complex in Pasay City. The book is a valuable chronicle on how the discipline and vision of a Filipino artist can create and sustain interest in what is considered an elite dance form.Written by Paolo Marko Manalo

Published 1987. Author, Bayanihan Folk Arts Center. Manila: Bayanihan Folk Arts Center.

The book is a collection of writings and pictures by the founder and members of the Bayanihan Dance Company. Bayanihan founder Helena Benitez opens the collection with an essay that looks back at Bayanihan’s 30 years of experience and explains the mission and meaning of the company. “Bayanihan” signifies a way of life, a synonym for “folk,” and the pride of Filipinos both in the Philippines and abroad. Jose Lardizabal’s “Barefoot on a High Plateau” prefaces the book reminiscing about the Bayanihan’s 1959 performance in New York.

The first section titled the “Bayanihan Story” by executive director Leticia Perez de Guzman claims that dance as part of the Filipino way of life is crucial in rediscovering our nation. The nationalist fervor in the 1940s and 1950s paved the way for the establishment of a national dance company. The Philippine Women’s University (PWU), then headed by Conrado and Francisca Benitez, spearheaded a project to explore and preserve the nation’s culture. Although folk dance had already been taught for 30 years on campus and the University’s Filipiniana Folk Music and Dance Committee had presented programs inspired by the studies of Francisca Reyes-Aquino, more efforts in cultural retrieval were made. Composer Lucrecia Kasilag, dance-researcher Aurora Dino, and ethnolinguist Jose Maceda did more research into music and dance in Mindoro, Palawan, and the Mountain Province. Further research on costumes and dances were later conducted by Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula and Manuel Cordova in the Southern Philippines. From the PWU Physical Education Club’s regular weekend performances of the retrieved dances, the group produced Magbayahihan Tayo (Let’s Help Each Other) to honor Pres Ramon Magsaysay in 1956. They presented Bayanihan: A Philippine Music and Dance Festival at the World Confederation of Organizations of the Teaching Professions in 1957 and founded the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company in 1958. By the time the company toured Europe, Latin America, Asia, and the United States in 1959, it had transformed dances gathered from the field into theatrical performances.

The section titled “Before Curtain-Rise, Backstage: The Planning, Artists” includes essays by people behind the company. Bayanihan’s artistic director Jose Lardizabal recalls how he was conscripted to help prepare the company for the 1958 Brussels Fair. He recounts how he taught company members the art of performing on stage. Choreographer and dance director Reyes-Urtula explains how Bayanihan had to assiduously learn dances and rituals from indigenous peoples, and to regularly consult the leaders of cultural communities before adapting the dances into modern and elaborate theater presentations. Reyes-Urtula discusses compression, enhancement, and highlighting as the major processes involved in transposing the dances from their original location to the theater. Music director Kasilag discusses the challenges of crafting music for the dance group. Working with indigenous and folk music, Kasilag tried to preserve tradition in the process of raising the music to the level of stage performance. Kasilag accomplished this by highlighting tone, color, and intensity through instrumentation. She elaborates on the sounds of indigenous instruments and folk songs unique to the different regions and how these are combined with Bayanihan’s Western-derived music. Costume director Isabel Santos narrates how she travelled around the Philippines in search of authentic materials that she could transform into garments for dancing. Considering the needs of the stage and the quick changes demanded by the repertoire, costume designs must be wearable and practical. Zippers and Velcro fasteners were easy devices used for all Bayanihan costumes.

The section “Oh Peregrine: High Notes and Anecdotes (Now and Then a Milestone),” comprises short writings on the exciting life of Bayanihan artists when abroad. Kasilag, Lardizabal, Reyes-Urtula, Rodrigo Perez III, Lourdes Guillermo, Nina Capistrano, Leni Cabili, Nina Yuson, and Corky Trinidad share unforgettable experiences in the face of challenges in creating dances, composing music, performing on stage, or dealing with adjustments needed in mounting productions abroad. The book ends with short but substantial entries on the people behind the dance company.

In the sections “Bayanihan in Black and White” and “Across Six Continents,” vibrant photographs document performances and tours of the company. Through the Bayanihan’s numerous performances around the world, the Filipino spirit has been made known to other culturesWritten by Ruth Jordana L. Pison

article_title: Body, Movement, and Culture: Kinesthetic and Visual Symbolism in a Philippine Community
text:
Published 1992. Author, Sally Ann Ness. Pennsylvania: University of Pennsylvania Press.

This is an ethnographic study of the popular traditional dance of Cebu called sinulog by American dance scholar and anthropologist Sally Ann Ness. Written in 13 chapters, the book builds on a thick descriptive account of the sinulog according to various readings of its meaning, practice, and representation. Ness examines its choreography and meaning as ritual and religious practice. She presents the dance tradition in the context of its city of origin. The devotees or customers buy candles from thetindera sinulog(female candle vendors) who dance while offering these to the Santo Niño at the cathedral. The author traces the history and development of the Troupe Sinulog and scrutinizes an actual event of the sinulog parade. The book ends with a discussion on the symbolic power of the sinulog phenomenon, its continuing resilience, its significance in contemporary times, and its historical and ethnographic value.

Inspired by Geertz’s interpretive ethnography and invoking Ness’s experience as dancer and choreographer, the book provides valuable insights from a Western researcher looking into a Philippine community’s cultural practices. It shows a strong researcher’s persona that has rigorously and sensitively interacted and lived within the community where sinulog was born and has continued to be practiced and developed. The book is an important work on the sinulog as a cultural phenomenon, invoking a perceptive and multilayered way of seeing a Philippine traditional dance phenomenon in the context of its history, society, and culture.Written by Rina Angela P. Corpus

article_title: Defiant Daughters Dancing: Three Independent Women Dance
text:
Published 2007. Author, Rina Angela Corpus. Quezon City: University of the Philippines (UP) Press.

The book was first written as the author’s master of arts thesis in art history at the University of the Philippines Diliman and was a recipient of the Outstanding MA Thesis Award from the UP Center for Women’s Studies Foundation in 2006. It looks at the lives and careers of three independent women choreographer-dancers in the Philippines: Myra Beltran, Kristin Jackson, and Agnes Locsin. Using a feminist framework, the book allows the voices of these three choreographer-dancers to tell their respective stories through interviews, as well as letters, journals, videos, reviews, and personality profiles that appeared in media. With the help of black-and-white pictures of the women as children and as adult performers, these sources show their paths as persons, performers, and choreographers.

The three choreographer-dancers are tied to a common ground: they trained to become classical ballerinas. Earlier they danced within a Western white aristocratic male canon that depicted female bodies as embodiments of the typical male fantasy of either ethereal sylphs or deadly sirens in pointe shoes. Despite the presence of other female dancers and choreographers before Locsin, Jackson, and Beltran, classical ballet and contemporary dance still tended to reinforce the male perspective with women playing the roles of passive princesses, peasant girls, or damsels in distress.

Quezon City-based Beltran, the New York Filipino-American Jackson, and Davao-bred Locsin have reclaimed the female body. They have defiantly gone independent, moving away from established dance companies, although they have occasionally collaborated with these cultural institutions. They have created their own studio spaces, trained dancers using a more liberating and gravity-bound aesthetics, and created works rooted in the Filipino experience. They have also resourcefully funded and sustained their endeavors without relying on ticket sales alone. Through their “disruptions” of and “trespasses” against the patriarchal dance system, the three independent artists reveal not only the story of their lives but also articulate the issues and concerns of many Filipino women dancers and choreographers.Written by Elizabeth Lolarga

article_title: Pangalay: Traditional Dances and Related Folk Artistic Expressions
text:
Published 1983. Author, Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa. Makati City: Filipinas Foundation, Inc.

This is the first book documenting the little-known and gradually disappearing Filipino indigenous dance pangalay —also known as igal (dance) among the Sama, Sama Dilaut (Badjao), and Jama Mapun; and pamansak (to dance)among the Yakan—and other folk cultural forms that flourished in the Sulu Archipelago. Fernando Amilbangsa provides a comprehensive, scholarly and, at the same time, practical information and intimate look at the dances gleaned over more than 20 years as a Tawi-Tawi resident, pangalay student, performer, and teacher. On-site as well as studio photographs provide essential documentary support for appreciation and preservation of southwestern Philippine culture, further enhanced by detailed illustrations of everyday objects that are cultural artifacts in danger of vanishing.

Chapter 1 is an overview of the three traditional dances of Sulu and Tawi-Tawi loosely classified according to form or style: (1) pangalay or igal, “the premier dance prototype;” (2) langka (mock combat); and (3) lunsay (communal song and dance). Aside from the lunsay dance notations, the author provides musical notation and lyrics of songs accompanying the dance steps.

Chapter 2 classifies traditional dances according to function, such as mimetic, occupational, courtship, martial, and ritual dances, with socio-cultural-historical glimpses into the maritime communities in which they took root.

Chapter 3 focuses on pangalay, its languid arm movements and gliding steps revealing its affinity to Asian classical dance styles originating from India. Postures and hand gestures are meticulously shown in the author’s silhouettes and close-up photos, revealing a concern for a system of instruction.

Chapter 4 describes the various items of male and female attire for everyday wear vis-a-vis those for dancing and other special events. More important is the chapter’s attempt to establish the authentic names of items of clothing, such assiyagfor the long tubular cloth worn diagonally across the chest from the left shoulder to the right hip, andsablayfor the loose-sleeved top paired withpatadjung(tubular skirt) orsawwal kantiu(loose trousers). Patterns for sewing and demonstrations of how they are worn are invaluable aids for saving intangible cultural heritage. Jewelry, especially in intricate designs on yellow gold, is given detailed attention, reflecting its traditional importance among the communities’ womenfolk, rich and poor alike.

Chapter 5 identifies properties, both special ones for dance such asjanggay(metal claws) andkalisorkris(sword), and everyday household objects such as baskets and oars. Exquisite samples ofpis(kerchief) andkandit(sash) point to complex weaving techniques that have made these rare treasures in many museums.

Chapter 6 describes instruments for traditional music and playing styles for listening and song and dance accompaniment. Most important are gongs, specifically thekulintangan, considered “one of the most sophisticated representatives of indigenous ensemble music in the Philippines” (2).

A distinct feature of the book, which attempts to address the problem of the impossibility of capturing dance in print, is the interactive flip book “animation” silhouettes of the author on the lower corner of each page. The book is not only informative and documentary, but also a persuasive argument for cultural preservation.

Pangalay won the National Book Award for Best Art Book in 1983.Written by Ma. Eloisa N. Francisco

Chapter 4 describes the various items of male and female attire for everyday wear vis-a-vis those for dancing and other special events. The book has an introductory chapter on the spiritual and material resources of Philippine culture, with historical references and illustrations. Many of the illustrations—colored and black-and-white—were specially taken on location.

article_title: Philippine Neo-Ethnic Choreography: A Creative Process
text:
Published 2012. Author, Agnes Locsin. Manila: University of Santo Tomas Publishing House.

The documentation of vanishing folk practices, rituals, and similar traditional forms by dance scholars and performing artists has enabled Agnes Locsin to draw materials and movements from the country’s different cultural groups and to recreate or reinvent them into a body of neo-ethnic dance works.

The author immersed in indigenous communities to study their dances that are usually prayers of petitions for a good harvest, thanksgiving, rites of passage or healing. From these field experiences, Locsin came up with a new (“neo”) vocabulary of stylized movements indebted to ethnic sources. These movements are fused with Western and modern dance techniques which enhanced Ballet Philippines’ repertoire of theater-dance productions such as Igorot, Bagobo, Moriones, Encantada (Enchantress), Paglalakbay (Journey), Taong Talangka (Human Crab), Elias, and La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution).

The book is divided into 10 chapters. All these chapters take the reader behind the scenes of the performances and production of the shows. “Ten Steps to Choreography” explains the process of creating a work from conceptualization, to research and immersion, to experiencing the scenographic space, to organizing the composition which includes inviting criticism and preparing for the performance.

“Transforming Ethnic to Neo-Ethnic” presents a number of methods that have proven helpful in her neo-ethnic choreography: stylizing, recreating/reinventing, and recapturing the qualities of tribal dances.

“Neo-Ethnic Choreography” provides two major examples of neo-ethnic works Locsin is known for: Igorot and Bagobo. The chapter presents the complex process involved in creating both works.

“Preparing for Encantada ” is an extensive discussion of several of Locsin’s works preceding Encantada. The works whose progeny and development are explained in detail in the chapter are Moriones and Hinilawod, choreographic creations which enabled Locsin to try out some ideas she already had in mind for Encantada, her major production.

The chapter “ Encantada ” traces the beginnings of the work to 1977, the year when Locsin, Joey Ayala, and Al Santos did their first collaborative work on a rock opera at the Ateneo de Davao University. Fifteen years later, when their proposal to restage the work with Ballet Philippines was declined by the company, Santos suggested Encantada, a work that will draw from some of Locsin’s earlier creations, including the Moriones and Hinilawod.

“Dances as Postscripts” elaborates on Paglalakbay and Labaw Donggon. The chapter provides the reader with details on these choreographic pieces, as results of collaborative efforts between researchers, musicians, chanters, set and costume designers, and dancers.

“Choreography for Competition” explains the dynamics between choice of music and choreography. While Locsin generally starts with movements, in Babalyan (Shaman), the music came first, chosen from among the five pieces sent by the competition organizers. Babalyan was created for the 1993 Tokyo International Choreography Competition. Other works done for competition are Taong Talangka for Camille Ordinario’s participation in the 6th Paris International Modern Dance Competition and Salome for her second round entry in the same contest.

The chapters on “ Elias ” and “ La Revolucion Filipina ” explore the development of neo-ethnic movements in rendering two narratives based on Philippine history. Notable about La RevolucionFilipina was how Locsin was able to make the character of the paralytic hero Apolinario Mabini “dance.” The battle of wills between Mabini and Aguinaldo was shown through the adept use of a hammock.

“Postscript” looks back at Locsin’s years of choreography, and the criticisms she had to face regarding her use of the term “neo-ethnic” and her so-called exoticization of materials.

Among the qualities of indigenous dances that the Davao-based choreographer learned are their repetitiveness and their being earthbound. The last is crucial. Unlike the movements of classical ballet that are ethereal and airborne, these steps require that the feet and toes touch the ground and feel the earth. If there are jumps, these are followed by crouching movements with bent knees.

The book includes short, first-person accounts from her creative collaborators like musician Joey Ayala; dancers Je An Salas, Annette Cruz Mariano, Ernest Mandap, Judell de Guzman-Sicam, Annie Divinagracia Sartorio, Grethel Domingo-Rampon, Biag Gaongen, Unita Gaye Galiluyo, and Camille Ordinario-Joson; and actor Nonie Buencamino.

From the dancers’ recollections, the common thread of their experience is how they had to reorient themselves from classical to modern ballet, shifting from lightness and pointed toes to groundedness and flexed toes. Rampon describes the Filipino dancers’ edge over classically trained French dancers in Paglalakbay —how naturally ethnic movements were expressed by the Filipinos, how hard it was for the French to do non-balletic hand movements.

Buencamino, a non-dancer who learned modern ballet for his acting-dancing role of Emilio Aguinaldo in La Revolucion Filipina, grew to respect the demands made on dancers to express the different aspects of literature through movements alone, unlike actors who have the luxury of discussing their characters’ motivations before rehearsals. Ayala describes Locsin as having the ability to crystallize “dance and shape it in her painstaking and patient detailing of movement, the process of which I find inspiring. She is a good giant on whose shoulders we might stand.”

Locsin’s definition of the neo-ethnic dance idiom is reinforced by black and white photographs which document the final productions and also illustrate how tribal movements are transposed and turned into modern steps. In the last chapter, she reflects on the place of neo-ethnic dance in the 21st century and states that although there still is a need for neo-ethnic choreography, she is also open to alternative terms and labels.

The book is not only a handy how-to guide for other choreographers who may want to take the neo-ethnic path but also Locsin’s contribution to the narrative of dance in the Philippines. It won the Alfonso T. Ongpin Prize for Best Book on Art during the 32nd National Book Award sponsored by the National Book Development Board and the Manila Critics Circle.Written by Elizabeth Lolarga and Ruth Jordana L. Pison

article_title: Sayaw: Dances of the Philippine Islands
text:
Published 1999, 2000, 2001, 2002, 2003, 2005, 2010, 2014. Editors, Larry Gabao and Franco Velas. Manila: Philippine Folk Dance Society (PFDS).

The eight volumes contain selected dances from the annual folk dance workshops of PFDS from 1999 to 2014. The dances were drawn from various regions, north to south from Batanes to Sulu, and east to west from Leyte to Palawan. They include Ivatan, Ibanag, the Cordillera, Kapampangan, Pangasinan, Zambal, Tagalog, Bicol, Samareño, Leyteño, Cebuano, Ilonggo, Maranao, Maguindanao, Manobo, Bukidnon, Blaan, Tboli, Subanon, and Tausug dances. The dances represent ritual, occupational , imitative, combat, courtship, social, and game dances. Provenance of dances is identified in terms of place and resource persons. Included too are dance instruction, musical scoring for each dance, and illustrations in black-and-white or color.

Volume 1 of Sayaw has habanera narciseña of San Narciso and sinublihan (to go back and forth),both of Zambales; lanceros (lancers) de Tayabas of Quezon; lapay (seagull) Bantigue of Bantigue Island, Masbate; likod-likod (back-to-back)of Leyte; man-manok (like fowls) of the Bago tribe of Ilocos Sur; mazurka de Jagna of Bohol; pahid (to wipe) and pitik mingaw (touch of loneliness) of Capiz; pampilpilalecan (touching palms)and valse vieja of Pangasinan; sayaw sa Cuyo (dance in Cuyo) of Cuyo, Palawan; sohten (a precombat dance of supplication) of the Subanon in Lapuyan, Zamboanga del Norte; sua-ku-sua (my pomelo tree) of Jolo; and valse ybanag of Camalingan, Cagayan.

Volume 2 has abaruray (fromabaor how, and Ruray, name of a place) of Catanauan, Quezon; ala fotta (jota-like) of the Gaddang in Santiago, Isabela; despedida (farewell) and karansa (frolic)of Capiz; dugso (ritual dance) of Lantapan, Bukidnon; galuyo (rooster) and sa aro no balo balo (newfound love) of Pangasinan; gaway-gaway (named aftergabi, taro plant) of Leyte; jota sevillana of Paete, Laguna; ossonet (fromOsse, Ibanag for St. Joseph) of Cagayan; palo-palo (stick or club) of the Ivatan of Batanes; pantomina ( mime) mayor of Sorsogon; polka biana (polka for Biana) of Zamboanga, Negros Oriental; pulosung (song-dance) Florida Blanca of Pampanga; and raragsakan (merry-making) of Lubuangan, Kalinga.

Volume 3 has bendian (a harvest, victory, celebration dance) of the Ibaloy and Kankanaey in Benguet; buling-buling (from the ash on the temple at Ash Wednesday) of Guilangan, Quezon; gaod (paddle) of Cabangan and polka ilwas of Olongapo, Zambales; idudu (lullaby) of Abra; itik-itik (duck-like) Sibonga of Sibonga, Cebu; kadal tahu (true dance) of Lake Sebu, South Cotabato; konan (named after an old one-peso coin) and sigsilew (with lights, in coconut shell) of Pangasinan; la jotaIsabela of Cauayan, Isabela; panulo sa baybayon (fishing by torch) of Cadiz, Negros Occidental; pasigin (ring-net, for fishing) of Capiz; rigodon royale of Zamboanguita, Negros Oriental; a la ti mais (corn dance) of the Ibanag in Isabela; and tiksiw (springing)of Aklan.

Volume 4 has agogocoy (mud crab) of Romblon; inalimango (crab-like) of Pan-ay, Capiz; janggay (metal claws) of Arena Blanco, Zamboanga del Sur; jota Quirino of Quirino province; kuratsa Zarraga of Zarraga, Iloilo; la simpatika (charming) of Pangasinan; miligoy (a man’s name) de Cebu of Consolacion, Cebu; nilambay (blue crab) of Tubigan, Bohol; panangasin (salt-making) of Pagudpud and zapatoti (tappingzapatillas)of Piddig, Ilocos Norte; pastores (shepherds) camalig of Albay; pag-Apir (about fans)of Maranao in Marawi; sida apo (fish for sale) of Cabangan, Zambales; and yano (fascinating) pandoniño of Pandan, Antique.

Volume 5 has buti-buti (small dug-out) of Jolo; cariñosa (charming) of Rapu-rapu, Albay; jota echagueña of Echague, Isabela; kadal-kafi (kafibird dance) of the Blaan in Davao del Sur; karatong (bamboo music instrument) of Cuyo, Palawan; kinaransa (to prance) of Kalibo, Aklan; kinugsikusik (squirrel-like) of the Manobo in Agusan del Sur; la jota sevillana of Janiuay, Iloilo; malagueña of Catanauan, Quezon; pamulad isda (drying fish) of Cadiz, Negros Occidental; pantomina (mime) de Sorsogon of Sorsogon;pastores (shepherds) tubog of Oas, Albay;putongan (crowning) Sta. Cruz of Marinduque; subli Agoncillo (ritual dance of Agoncillo) of Batangas; and uyaoy (grand festival) of Mayaoyao, Ifugao.

Volume 6 has agalukan (of clam gatherers) of Subic, Zambales; bailo de las pastores (dance of shepherds) of Ibajay, Aklan; ballangbang (term for dance in celebration) of the Applay tribe in Mountain Province;bayluhan (dance to honor San Pascual Baylon) of Navotas, Rizal; kasadyahan (joy) of Negros Occidental; komintang (term in music, for hand gesture, even about war) of Batangas; madrileña (of Madrid) of Bayambang, Pangasinan; maglanka (to dance) of the Tausug in Sulu; molinero (mill or miller) of Paete, Laguna; pandanggo sa bulig (mudfish) of Bocaue, Bulacan; silong sa ganding of Maguindanao; sinakiki (flirtation) of Rapu-rapu, Albay; tadjok (term for a dance) of Labuangan, Kalinga; and tarektek (woodpecker) of Mt Data, Benguet, Mountain Province.

Volume 7 has amaemayatok (woodpecker) of the Manobo in Agusan del Sur; banga (clay pot) in Kalinga; espanyola (Spanish-like) of San Vicente, Camarines Norte; gozos (song of praise) of Santiago, Isabela; sampaguita and jota de Medellin of Medellin and sampaguitabothin Cebu; kapa-malong (manipulating themalong) of Maguindanao; kiriwkiw (to shake) of Ibajay, Aklan; maral fkuradang nga (putting the baby to sleep) of the Blaan in Malapatan, South Cotabato; pagdurang (gold-panning) of Aroroy, Masbate; pami-paramang (to court) of the Zambal in Palauig, Zambales; regatones (roving fish vendors) of Cadiz, Negros Occiental; sabunganay (banana blossom) of Paoay, Ilocos Norte; and tay-yu (dance for courtship, at wedding) of Ifugao.

Volume 8 has inagta (offering)of Siaton, Negros Oriental; jota camarines of Daet, Camarines Norte; jota de Olongapo of Zambales; pang-abi-abi (welcome) of Libacao, Aklan; pangalimango (crab-like) of Aroroy, Masbate; pangibog (mimicking seduction) of the Manobo in Agusan del Sur; pansak si laley (dance on top of plates) of Lamitan, Basilan; pastores (shepherds) kawit of Medellin, Cebu; saut sa raug (dance on bamboo tubes) of Passai, Iloilo; sayaw ecijana of Cabanatuan, Nueva Ecija; sotis (schottische) batan of Batan, Aklan; and takiling (a kind of bird) of Kalinga.

These volumes present an impressive number of folk dance researchers from various parts of the country who have presented and taught dances in the annual PFDS dance workshops. Some of the prominent ones like Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, Paz Cielo Belmonte, Jovita Sison Friese, Teresita Ines, Emerita Basilio, Ramon Obusan, Cesar Nimor, Petronila Suarez, Jose Balcena, and Crisostomo Barrera, pursued their commitment to dance scholarship despite their limited funds and time. A good number of them presented more than one dance in the workshops. There are also resource persons who further dance research: Emma Acevedo, Juana Roque Afuang, Jose Alvarez, Estelita Aquino, Mila Ancheta, Nina Ardiente, Minerva Atanacio, Hermes Avellana, Mamerta Basobas, Asuncion Bonoan, Romulo Bugna, Araceli Campos, Virginia Coscos, Mila Layugan Dancel, Rubin Demonteverde, Eunice Dionele, Ester Dula, Dominador Eli, Antonio Estacion, Mario Rodriguez Eugenio, Zosimo Figuero, John Fontillas, Jaime Grulla, Eufracio Gumpal, Mila Catelo Janson, Thadema Labagala, Ruth Laylo, Antonio Li, Mary Ann Lopez, Maria Chelo Loque, Raquel Magalona, Marilyn Mecenario Manaloto, Loretta Manlupig, Evangeline Martines, Edwin Masangcay, Ronnie Mirabuena, Remigio Monroe, Crisostomo Oscaris, Elsie Padeo, Earl Francis Pasilan, Franco Pastor, Jess de Paz, Jaime Pumakis, Jay-ar de la Rosa, and Milagros Vasquez. They speak of how PFDS has continued to inspire dance teachers and researchers since Francisca Reyes-Aquino founded it in 1949.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

article_title: Subli: One Dance in Four Voices (Subli: Isang Sayaw sa Apat na Tinig)
text:
Published, 1989. Author, Elena Rivera Mirano. Manila: Museo ng Kalinangang Pilipino, Cultural Resources and Communications Services, Cultural Center of the Philippines.

The book is mainly authored and researched by Elena Rivera Mirano, an art and music scholar, choir conductor, and singer. It was done in collaboration with photographer Neal M. Oshima, dance scholar and notator Basilio Esteban Villaruz, and with additional concepts from Marian Pastor Roces and Glenna Aquino.

The book provides a multilayered reading of the traditional dance form subli of Batangas as a complex system of music, literature, dance, prayer, and religious practice. Each of the chapters of the book speaks of the subli from a different perspective or voice. The first chapter contains the “voice” of a matremayo (traditional subli lead performer) using the interview as methodology. The second chapter, “Portfolio of Portraits,” is a collection of portraits of a number of manunubli (subli dancers)together with select statements from the performers and song-text fragments from the traditional practice. The third chapter, “The Historical Record Speaks,” contains excerpts of two historical texts: “The Holy Cross of Bauan,” 1790, by Pedro Amuedo de Castro, and “100">Subli,” 1888, by Wenceslao Retana. De Castro speaks of the religious origins of the Holy Cross as an icon of devotion of the subli practice and its possible origins in Bauan, Batangas, while Retana provides a description of the movements involved in the subli as dance. The fourth chapter, “The Subli Speaks,” is a compilation of actual song-texts from select towns of Batangas, together with the musical and dance notations. The last chapter, “The Observer Speaks,” is a final word by Mirano encapsulating the research experience and its lessons and insights, highlighting subli as bothlaro(game) andpanata(vow), while revealing the subtle layers of the subli as a complex art form, devotional ritual, and gendered dance movement.

Offering a multisided approach in looking at a traditional Philippine dance practice and using a rigorous and sensitive cultural research methodology, the book is an important contribution toward modern readers’ understanding, not only of subli’s subtle aesthetic elements, but also toward the use of a collaborative and cross-disciplinary approach in researching and writing about Philippine traditional art, dance, and culture.Written by Rina Angela P. Corpus

article_title: The Dances of the Emerald Isles
text:
Published 1980. Author, LeonorOrosa-Goquingco. Quezon City: Ben-Lor Publishers.

This book is the first to focus deeply and comprehensively on the ethnic and folk dances of the Philippines. It describes the Filipino people and their myth, history, and geographical distribution. It is replete with authoritative references and maps. It has an overview of the dances, music, and arts of the ethnic Filipinos. Then, it is divided into detailed discussions of the dances of indigenous groups: the Bontok, Ifugao, Benguet, Apayao, and Kalinga in the north; the Aeta, Mangyan, Tinguian, Bugkalot aka Ilongot, Ikalahan, Tagbanwa, Batak, and Palawan of the north and central Philippines; the Bagobo, Manobo, Talaingod, Tagakaulo, Mansaka, Mandaya, Tboli, Blaan, Bukidnon, Tiruray, and Subanon of Mindanao; the Muslim groups in the south, which are the Tausug, Sama, Sama Dilaut aka Badjao, Yakan, JamaMapun, Maguindanao, and Maranao; and the Christianized Filipinos who have absorbed much Western influence in their dances and way of life. It discusses the researches of FranciscaReyes-Aquino, AntoninoBuenaventura, and Emilia Reysio-Cruz. The author quotes Martha Graham who said that “to be great, art must become indigenous” and “belong to the country in which it flourishes and not be a pale copy of some art form perfected by another culture and another people.”

In her preface, Orosa-Goquingco stresses the identity of the Filipinos in their dances without losing track of the universality of the dance as a language and as “a veritable mirror reflective of the deepest sensibilities of the human spirit.” Even as she regrets the “paucity of comprehensive material” in Philippine folkways and dances, she is assured of a comprehensive coverage of “principal types,” given authenticity and conviction by her own personal field researches.

The book contains black-and-white and colored photographs, mostly candid and illustrative, of instruments, costumes, and accessories. Included are an essay on Southeast Asian music by JoseMaceda and another essay praising the author’s choreographic work, particularly her Filipinescas: Philippine Life,Legend, and Lore in Dance, by National Artist NickJoaquin. There is also a very useful bibliography at the end.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

article_title: The Day the Dancers Stayed: Performing in the Philippine/American Diaspora
text:
Published 2010. Author, Theodore S. Gonzalves. Philadelphia: Temple University Press.

The book’s Prologue provides a social and historical background for the study, from the 1898 battle for Manila, to the seditious plays of 1902 to 1916, and over a century later, the year 1997. This framing later questions the nation’s official account of the seemingly timeless “special relationship” between the Philippines and the United States. The introduction interweaves diverse historical accounts of national and global issues, intergenerational dialogues and antagonisms, youth culture, dance theory, ethnography, security and international relations, agricultural and service labor, migration, mass-based struggles, civil rights, and social justice. With this background, Gonzalves traces the genealogy of the “Pilipino Cultural Night” (PCN), a cultural programming popular among Filipino students in the United States and Canada since the 1980s. The book’s title parodies the short story “The Day the Dancers Came” by the Filipino American writer Bienvenido Santos, first published in 1970.

The first chapter, “The Art of the State: Inventing Folkloric Forms (Manila, 1934),” focuses on the creation of a “national performance repertoire,” and a touristic popularization of a dance-theater form. It accounts for the creation of PCN by narrating the foundational work undertaken by educators in the 1930s, such as the romantic nationalist and then president of the University of the Philippines Jorge Bocobo, and the physical educator and folklorist Francisca Reyes (later Mrs. Tolentino, then Mrs. Aquino). Both are credited with the invention of a national folkloric repertoire, which proved to be a crucial tool to instill “kinetic nationalism” into Filipino bodies.

The second chapter, “Take It from the People: Dancing Diplomats and the Cultural Authenticity (Brussels, 1958),” discusses the folk dances adapted into “dance-theater” as they migrated from schools to the concert halls in the 1950s and 1960s. This is exemplified by the celebrated Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company based in the Philippine Women’s University, and the Far Eastern University Dance Troupe. Owing to political sponsors and educators in Manila who invented a national dance theater, they showed the range of Philippine traditions in the international scene. Other troupes that followed in the international scene were the Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe, the Filipinescas Dance Company, and the Tambuli Cultural Troupe. Their work defined for PCN the performative vocabulary of Philippine culture. Against this scenario, folkloric forms were reinterpreted by US-based students.

The third chapter, “Dancing into Oblivion: The Pilipino Cultural Night (Los Angeles, 1983),” focuses on a PCN called “Kasaysayan ng Lahi” (History of the People) at the University of California in Los Angeles (UCLA). It marked the beginning of a unique genre of Filipino-American expression and showed a dynamic version of Filipino-American culture in the wake of unabated immigration of underemployed Filipino professionals. The chapter elaborates on how the PCN became a source of improvised kinetic education. The shows mirrored cross-cultural struggles—racial, political, social, and economic—experienced by Filipino migrants and Filipino-Americans.

The fourth chapter, “Repetitive Motion: The Mechanics of Reverse Exile (San Francisco, 1993),” highlights a few major elements of the PCN and discloses the PCN’s degeneration into ritualistic artifacts. The story which includes the history of Filipino student organizations related to the PCN contextualizes the migrations of Filipinos to the US. The chapter details the time, manpower, and logistics expended for performances, the major elements that furthered the development of the PCN, plus the internal and external criticisms about it. The chapter also elucidates on the “reverse exile” motif, familiar in the PCN genre. Reflected in this is the quest for cultural identity or the “missing” something and the “crisis” of Filipino-Americans, meant to be resolved by an imagined return to the idyllic Philippines.

The fifth chapter, “Making a Mockery of Everything We Hold True and Dear, Exploring Parody with the Tongue in the Mood (TM) production of ‘PCN Salute’ (San Francisco, 1997),” presents a comedy theater group that satirized the PCN performances. It was “parody from the inside” cued from Dario Fo, the Italian playwright and Nobel Prize winner for literature in 1997. Spiritedly narrated was the work of Tongue in the Mood, a group composed of veteran PCN artists. “PCN Salute” spoofed the PCN, implying that it needs to be dynamic with its repertoire and identities going beyond entertainment and should ask questions about power, place, and imagination. With TM, the PCN found its own cultural critique.

In tracing the genealogy of the PCN genre as an expressive cultural form developed by Filipino-Americans, the book shows that the function of imported cultural practices is fickle, as each generation of teachers and students adroitly remix and reinvent those “authentic” cultural forms or “official modes” of conceiving the past. In “Epilogue: Memoria,” Gonzalves describes the phantom pain of his father, a retired sergeant in the US Army who lost his left arm in an accident. Gonzalves connects this to his own muscle memory during his piano lessons. It is muscle memory in the hands, the fingers, and the wrists that carries the information enabling the body to connect to the environment, called “proprioception.” Both phantom pain and muscle memory are used to explain Gonzalves’s and the PCN performers’ ability to embrace or connect to expressive folkloric forms or performance vocabulary of Philippine culture, as if they had experienced these before. It is as if the Philippine traditions incorporated in the PCN repertoire were, and still are, part of themselves.Written by Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa

article_title: Treading Through 45 Years of Philippine Dance
text:
Published, 2006. Author, Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz. Quezon City: The University of the Philippines Press and the Philippine Folklife Museum Foundation, San Francisco, California, USA.

The book is an extensive scholarly chronicle of dance history in the Philippines and the dance world. It focuses on the state of the art, the events, and personalities—both the distinguished and the lesser known practitioners—who studied and researched, taught and wrote, promoted and popularized, swayed and pirouetted on the Philippine dance landscape. Philippine culture and society unfold beyond dance scholarship and performance with insightful or thought-provoking commentaries allied with local, national, and international concerns such as ethnicity, gender, politics, economics, tourism, religion, education, research, theater, music, history, and culture.

“What Is Dance” discusses the nature and methods of dance scholarship and criticism. Included is the synthesis of Villaruz in the form of a Dance Globe, a graphic summary that serves as an aide-memoire in the study of dance. Villaruz bares circumstances that breed dance critics in the Philippines. A brief but equally engrossing topic is about the “Filipino soul in dance” that attests to the peoples’ creative identity forged under every imaginable circumstance. Given ample space are dance research, analysis, and problems of documentation, performance, and choreography in the 21st century.

“Where Is Philippine Dance” includes ballet history in the Philippines, admonishing the Filipino to feel confident to dance on his/her own terms and to use his/her own resources. The East-West connection or fusion in dance dwells on the creative ability of the Filipino choreographers to “indigenize” foreign music through native subjects. Enlightening is the essay on the role of dance in nation building, and of government in sustaining cultural creativity. Villaruz challenges the legitimacy of favored groups to project Philippine identity and ethnicity in dance at home and abroad. Questioned is how folk dance styles are preserved and documented.

“How Is Dance” is an incisive and broad comparative analysis of the achievements of Filipino choreographers, based on homegrown folkloric or indigenous and universal themes. Villaruz articulates the problem of dance preservation and archival documentation of tradition and change in the last 50 years. He poses important questions that may help appraise the state of Philippine dance: How many see a folk dance performance or ballet? How many know Philippine dance history? How encouraging are we in molding more creative talents? How can the government and private sector sustain regional efforts? How restrictive is the bureaucracy with regard to projects on dance experimentation and research?

“Teaching Dance” provides a view on the study of dance through history and anthropology; aesthetics and semiotics; and movement as text/language and metaphor. The essays on the technical and theoretical components of dance are helpful in understanding the dancing body. The cultural identity of a dancing body is an educational concern—thus, the profile of a dance teacher as scholar is included.

“Reading, Writing” expounds on why dance criticism requires a greater understanding of dance vocabulary or “language,” and underscores the importance of the body as dance instrument. It also delves into the making of dance with the use of costuming, lighting, new technology, and the necessity of literacy through notation in aid of dance research and preservation. It also asks “what we have done to our dances,” about the absence of writing about new or less famous dance talents, and on what has been done in the realm of traditional arts by folk dancers, performers, scholars, and critics altogether.

“Who Is Dance” enumerates the triumphs of established dance companies, best exemplified by the Bayanihan, and the dedicated people in the Philippine dance firmament whose contributions as dance artists and teachers shaped the growth of dance in the country. Published 2012. Author, Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz. Manila: University of Santo Tomas Publishing House.

This collection, by dancer, choreographer, critic, and professor of dance Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, is a three-volume compendium of essays, reviews, dance and theater history, and social biographies of artists written from the 1960s to the 1990s.

The first volume is divided into four parts: “Thoughts on Dance,” “Criticism,” “Choreography,” and “Dance Reviews.” It sets forth the theoretical framework used in the analyses of dance and theater in the Philippines. Part one shares with the reader ways of seeing dance, its clarity and complexity, its ephemerality, and legacy. Villaruz calls for the understanding of various dance genres characterized by several styles, diverse movement expressions, and numerous motivations. Part two has critical essays and illustrates the demanding task of critical reading and writing, both requiring a deep knowledge of dance history, aesthetics, culture, anthropology, and dance reception and consumption. Villaruz stresses the reality that a Filipino dance critic is a juggler of professions; he may be a dancer/choreographer, teacher, and critic all at the same time. Part three consists of reviews on choreographic works against their political and cultural backgrounds. In these essays, Villaruz is consistent in his critical stance on the creation of a national dance company which he feels will curtail the development of dance in the country. In the last part of the volume, Villaruz pays tribute to Filipino dance artists who have remained committed to their art, both in the Philippines and abroad. Some of them are Anna Villadolid, Rupert Acuña, Nicolas Pacaña, Hazel Zabas, Jojo Lucila, Alden Lugnasin, Dwight Rodrigazo, and Myra Beltran.

The second volume has three parts: “Dance History/Historical Marks,” “Folk Dance,” and “Dance Reviews.” The volume addresses the nature and function of choreographic art as public expression or exhibition. In part one, Villaruz discusses Philippine dance history in terms of the creative output of dancers, performing groups, and institutions. In all of these essays, Villaruz recognizes the distinct talent of the Filipino dancer and choreographer. In part two, the readings highlight the contribution of the country’s various folk dance groups to the preservation of the country’s cultural heritage, as exemplified by the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group, and the Filipinescas. Nonetheless, Villaruz calls attention to a very basic issue yet to be resolved: the definition of “folk” or “ethnographic subject.” He suggests a more critical awareness of the difference between revival, survival, and transformation in dealing with the staging of rituals, rural, and “ethnic dances.” In the last part of the volume, Villaruz’s dance reviews reveal an informed critical position based on years of experience in both choreography and performance. The analysis of every performance is a mix of dance history, lessons in aesthetics, explorations of movement, analyses of bodies, commentaries on stage design, evaluation of music, and discussions on the politics of dance.

The third volume has two parts: “Thoughts on Theater” and “Theater Reviews.” The volume shows the critic’s knowledge of both literature and theater as these are either read or viewed as performances. The essays in the first part expound on Villaruz’s general ideas on theater, its nature, its process of creation and production, and the mindset of its audience. The essays take the reader from the 1960s to the 1990s. He laments the Filipinos’ lack of commitment to theater but eventually becomes more optimistic as theater became more audacious and adventurous. In “Theater Reviews,” he comments on the playwright’s text, the performers’ acting, the director’s choices, the choreography, staging techniques, stage design, music, and singing. A significant contribution to the history of theater in the Philippines, the essays document what the Filipinos have achieved in the performing arts. Theater companies—huge and small, old and new, traditional and experimental—attest to such achievement. Some of these companies are Repertory Philippines, Teatro Pilipino, Philippine Educational Theater Association, UP Repertory, Dulaang UP, UP Tropa, UP Mobile Theater, and Kaliwat Theater Collective. Villaruz also gives ample recognition to the directors who have kept Philippine theater alive and dynamic. Some of them are Zenaida Amador, Baby Barredo, Rolando Tinio, Tony Mabesa, Jonas Sebastian, Behn Cervantes, Nonon Padilla, Anton Juan, Alex Cortez, Auraeus Solito, and Chris Martinez.

As the three-volume collection covers both mainstream and non-mainstream performances and artists, Walking Through Philippine Theater is a valuable contribution to the scholarship on dance and theater in the Philippines.Written by Ruth Jordana L. Pison
